column1: ap 02:00|"two o’clock"|"‘I say
column2: Jeeves
column3: a man I met at the club last night told me to put my shirt on Privateer for the two o’clock race this afternoon. How about it?’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:30|One-thirty|"‘Oh
column2: all right
column3: ’ I said. ‘But
column4: when you say you haven’t nerve enough for any dashed thing in the world
column5: you misjudge yourself. A fellow who-‘

column1: ‘Cheerio!’ said young Bingo. ‘One-thirty tomorrow. Don’t be late.’
I’m bound to say that the more I contemplated the binge
column2: the less I liked it. It was all very well for Bingo to say that I was slated for a magnificent lunch; but what good is the best possible lunch to a fellow if he is slung out into the street on his ear during the soup course? However
column3: the word of a Wooster is his bond and all that sort of rot
column4: so at one-thirty next day I tottered up the steps of No. 16
column5: Pounceby Gardens
column6: and punched the bell. And half a minute later I was in the drawing-room
column7: shaking hands with the fattest man I have ever seen in my life."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 12:00|midday|"I had gone to earth in my suite one evening and for the first time that day was feeling that life wasn’t so bad after all. Right through the day from lunch-time I’d had the Hemmingway girl on my hands
column2: Aunt Agatha having shooed us off together immediately after the midday meal. The result was
column3: as I looked down on the lighted promenade and saw all the people popping happily about on their way to dinner and the Casino and what not
column4: a kind of wistful feeling came over me. I couldn’t help thinking how dashed happy I could have contrived to be in this place if only Aunt Agatha and the other blisters had been elsewhere."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 09:00|"nine o’clock"|"‘Mr Wooster
column2: ’ she cried
column3: ‘won’t you
column4: won’t you help us? Oh
column5: do say you will! We must have the money to get back the cheque from Colonel Musgrave before nine o’clock - he leaves on the nine-twenty. I was at my wits’ end what to do when I remembered how kind you had always been. Mr Wooster
column6: will you lend Sidney the money and take these as security?’ And before I knew what she was doing she had dived into her bag
column7: produced a case
column9: ’ she said. ‘I don’t know what they are worth - they were a present from my poor father -‘"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 09:20|nine-twenty|"‘Mr Wooster
column2: ’ she cried
column3: ‘won’t you
column4: won’t you help us? Oh
column5: do say you will! We must have the money to get back the cheque from Colonel Musgrave before nine o’clock - he leaves on the nine-twenty. I was at my wits’ end what to do when I remembered how kind you had always been. Mr Wooster
column6: will you lend Sidney the money and take these as security?’ And before I knew what she was doing she had dived into her bag
column7: produced a case
column9: ’ she said. ‘I don’t know what they are worth - they were a present from my poor father -‘"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 10:00|"Ten o’clock"|"‘Ten o’clock
column2: a clear night
column3: and all’s well
column4: Jeeves
column5: ’ I said
column6: breezing back into the good old suite."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:15|one-fifteen|"‘This is my lunch. I’ve got to meet Oswald at Waterloo at one-fifteen
column2: to catch the train back. I brought him up to town to see the dentist.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:45|one-forty-five|"The blow fell precisely at one-forty-five (summer time). Spenser
column2: Aunt Agatha’s butler
column3: was offering me the fried potatoes at the moment
column4: and such was my emotion that I lofted six of them on to the sideboard with the spoon. Shaken to the core
column5: if you know what I mean."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:30|one-thirty|"‘Claude did not say. Truth or knowledge
column2: I should imagine. It is evidently a very desirable club to belong to
column3: for Claude added that Lord Rainsby
column4: the Earl of Datchet’s son
column5: was one of his fellow candidates. However
column6: we are wandering from the point
column7: which is that Sir Roderick wants to have a quiet talk with you quite alone. Now I rely on you
column9: to be - I won’t say intelligent
column10: but at least sensible. Don’t giggle nervously; try to keep that horrible glassy expression out of your eyes; don’t yawn or fidget; and remember that Sir Roderick is the president of the West London branch of the anti-gambling league
column11: so please do not talk about horse-racing. He will lunch with you at your flat tomorrow at one-thirty. Please remember that he drinks no wine
column13: and can only eat the simplest food
column14: owing to an impaired digestion. Do not offer him coffee
column15: for he considers it the root of half the nerve-trouble in the world.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 03:10|three-ten|"‘Oh
column2: buzzing round. We’re just up for the day. Flying visit
column3: strictly unofficial. We oil back on the three-ten. And now
column4: touching that lunch you very decently volunteered to stand us
column5: which shall it be? Ritz? Savoy? Carlton? Or
column6: if you’re a member of Giro’s or the Embassy
column7: that would do just as well.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:40|"twenty to two"|"I hadn’t time to stop and argue. I unbelted the fiver and hopped into the cab. It was twenty to two when I got to the flat. I bounded into the sitting-room
column2: but it was empty."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 07:45|seven-forty-five|"He would seem from contemporary accounts to have blown in one morning at seven-forty-five
column2: that being the ghastly sort of hour they shoot you off the liner in New York. He was given the respectful raspberry by Jeeves
column3: and told to try again about three hours later
column4: when there would be a sporting chance of my having sprung from my bed with a glad cry to welcome another day and all that sort of thing. Which was rather decent of Jeeves
column5: by the way
column6: for it so happened that there was a slight estrangement
column7: a touch of coldness
column8: a bit of a row in other words
column9: between us at the moment because of some rather priceless purple socks which I was wearing against his wishes: and a lesser man might easily have snatched at the chance of getting back at me a bit by loosing Cyril into my bedchamber at a moment when I couldn’t have stood a two-minutes’ conversation with my dearest pal. For until I have had my early cup of tea and have brooded on life for a bit absolutely undisturbed
column10: I’m not much of a lad for the merry chit-chat."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap < 01:00|"towards one o’clock"|"I was looking for Cyril to show up again any time after breakfast
column2: but he didn’t appear: so towards one o’clock I trickled out to the Lambs Club
column3: where I had an appointment to feed the Wooster face with a cove of the name of Caffyn I’d got pally with since my arrival - George Caffyn
column4: a fellow who wrote plays and what not. I’d made a lot of friends during my stay in New York
column5: the city being crammed with bonhomous lads who one and all extended a welcoming hand to the stranger in their midst."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ~ 15:00|"about three in the afternoon"|"this jolly old part of mine. How ought I to dress it? What I mean is
column2: the first act scene is laid in an hotel of sorts
column3: at about three in the afternoon. What ought I to wear
column4: do you think?’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 08:00|eight|"The thing was billed to start at eight o’clock
column2: so I rolled up at ten-fifteen
column3: so as not to have too long to wait before they began. The dress-parade was still going on. George was on the stage
column4: talking to a cove in shirt-sleeves and an absolutely round chappie with big spectacles and a practically hairless dome. I had seen George with the latter merchant once or twice at the club
column5: and I knew that he was Blumenfield
column6: the manager. I waved to George
column7: and slid into a seat at the back of the house
column8: so as to be out of the way when the fighting started. Presently George hopped down off the stage and came and joined me
column9: and fairly soon after that the curtain went down. The chappie at the piano whacked out a well-meant bar or two
column10: and the curtain went up again."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 10:15|ten-fifteen|"The thing was billed to start at eight o’clock
column2: so I rolled up at ten-fifteen
column3: so as not to have too long to wait before they began. The dress-parade was still going on. George was on the stage
column4: talking to a cove in shirt-sleeves and an absolutely round chappie with big spectacles and a practically hairless dome. I had seen George with the latter merchant once or twice at the club
column5: and I knew that he was Blumenfield
column6: the manager. I waved to George
column7: and slid into a seat at the back of the house
column8: so as to be out of the way when the fighting started. Presently George hopped down off the stage and came and joined me
column9: and fairly soon after that the curtain went down. The chappie at the piano whacked out a well-meant bar or two
column10: and the curtain went up again."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap ~ 10:30|"About half past ten"|"About half past ten next morning
column2: just after I had finished lubricating the good old ulterior with a soothing cup of Oolong
column3: Jeeves filtered into my bedroom
column4: and said that Cyril was waiting to see me in the sitting-room."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 17:00|"five in the afternoon"|"Funny how one changes as the years roll on. At school
column2: I remember
column3: I would cheerfully have sold my soul for scrambled eggs and sardines at five in the afternoon; but somehow
column4: since reaching man’s estate
column5: I had rather dropped out of the habit; and I’m bound to admit I was appalled to a goodish extent at the way the sons and daughter of the Revolution shoved their heads down and went for the foodstuffs. Even Comrade Butt cast off his gloom for a space and immersed his whole being in scrambled eggs
column6: only coming to the surface at intervals to grab another cup of tea. Presently the hot water gave out
column7: and I turned to Jeeves."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 05:10|five-ten|"‘Right-o
column2: then. Pack our spare dickey and a toothbrush in a neat brown-paper parcel
column3: send a wire to Lord Wickhammersley to say we’re coming
column4: and buy two tickets on the five-ten at Paddington tomorrow.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 05:10|five-ten|"The five-ten was late as usual
column2: and everybody was dressing for dinner when I arrived at the Hall. It was only by getting into my evening things in record time and taking the stairs to the dining-room in a couple of bounds that I managed to dead-heat with the soup. I slid into the vacant chair
column3: and found that I was sitting next to old Wickhammersley’s youngest daughter
column4: Cynthia."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap ~ 06:30|"about six-thirty"|"At this moment Jeeves came in with the good old beverage
column2: and I sprang on it with a glad cry. After a couple of sips things looked a bit brighter. Even young Bingo didn’t offend the eye to quite such an extent. By the time I’d finished the first cup I was a new man
column3: so much so that I not only permitted but encouraged the poor fish to read the rest of the bally thing
column4: and even went so far as to criticize the scansion of the fourth line of the fifth verse. We were still arguing the point when the door burst open and in blew Claude and Eustace. One of the things which discourages me about rural life is the frightful earliness with which events begin to break loose. I’ve stayed at places in the country where they’ve jerked me out of the dreamless at about six-thirty to go for a jolly swim in the lake. At Twing
column5: thank heaven
column6: they know me
column7: and let me breakfast in bed. The twins seemed pleased to see me. ‘Good old Bertie!’ said Claude."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 02:00|"two o’clock"|"‘Good man!’ said Bingo. ‘Now I can see daylight. Say I have a tenner on Heppenstall
column2: and cop; that’ll give me a bit in hand to back Pink Pill with in the two o’clock at Gatwick the week after next; cop on that
column3: put the pile on Musk-Rat for the one-thirty at Lewes
column4: and there I am with a nice little sum to take to Alexandra Park on September the tenth
column5: when I’ve got a tip straight from the stable.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:30|one-thirty|"‘Good man!’ said Bingo. ‘Now I can see daylight. Say I have a tenner on Heppenstall
column2: and cop; that’ll give me a bit in hand to back Pink Pill with in the two o’clock at Gatwick the week after next; cop on that
column3: put the pile on Musk-Rat for the one-thirty at Lewes
column4: and there I am with a nice little sum to take to Alexandra Park on September the tenth
column5: when I’ve got a tip straight from the stable.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 01:53|seven-to-two|"The worst of these country meetings is that you can’t plunge as heavily as you would like when you get a good thing
column2: because it alarms the Ring. Steggles
column3: though pimpled
column4: was
column5: as I have indicated
column6: no chump
column7: and if I had invested all I wanted to he would have put two and two together. I managed to get a good solid bet down for the syndicate
column9: though it did make him look thoughtful. I heard in the next few days that he had been making searching inquiries in the village concerning Harold; but nobody could tell him anything
column10: and eventually he came to the conclusion
column12: that I must be having a long shot on the strength of that thirty-yards start. Public opinion wavered between Jimmy Goode
column19: was offered to the public at two-to-one but found no takers."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"I must say I got a bit fed up with young Bingo in the next few days. It’s all very well for a fellow with a big winner in his stable to exercise proper care
column2: but in my opinion Bingo overdid it. The blighter’s mind appeared to be absolutely saturated with racing fiction; and in stories of that kind
column3: as far as I could make out
column4: no horse is ever allowed to start in a race without at least a dozen attempts to put it out of action. He stuck to Harold like a plaster. Never let the unfortunate kid out of his sight. Of course
column5: it meant a lot to the poor old egg if he could collect on this race
column6: because it would give him enough money to chuck his tutoring job and get back to London; but all the same
column7: he needn’t have woken me up at three in the morning twice running - once to tell me we ought to cook Harold’s food ourselves to prevent doping: the other time to say that he had heard mysterious noises in the shrubbery. But he reached the limit
column9: when he insisted on my going to evening service on Sunday
column10: the day before the sports."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"I must say I got a bit fed up with young Bingo in the next few days. It’s all very well for a fellow with a big winner in his stable to exercise proper care
column2: but in my opinion Bingo overdid it. The blighter’s mind appeared to be absolutely saturated with racing fiction; and in stories of that kind
column3: as far as I could make out
column4: no horse is ever allowed to start in a race without at least a dozen attempts to put it out of action. He stuck to Harold like a plaster. Never let the unfortunate kid out of his sight. Of course
column5: it meant a lot to the poor old egg if he could collect on this race
column6: because it would give him enough money to chuck his tutoring job and get back to London; but all the same
column7: he needn’t have woken me up at three in the morning twice running - once to tell me we ought to cook Harold’s food ourselves to prevent doping: the other time to say that he had heard mysterious noises in the shrubbery. But he reached the limit
column9: when he insisted on my going to evening service on Sunday

column1: ‘Why on earth?’ I said
column2: never being much of a lad for evensong.

column1: ‘Well
column2: I can’t go myself. I shan’t be here. I’ve got to go to London today with young Egbert.’ Egbert was Lord Wickhammersley’s son
column3: the one Bingo was tutoring. ‘He’s going for a visit down in Kent
column4: and I’ve got to see him off at Charing Cross. It’s an infernal nuisance. I shan’t be back till Monday afternoon. In fact
column5: I shall miss most of the sports
column6: I expect. Everything
column7: therefore

column1: ap 00:50|"ten to one"|"‘Thirty quid at ten to one. I thought he must have heard something
column2: but apparently not. The race went by the form-book all right.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 02:00|"two AM"|"I didn’t hear a word from Bingo for a couple of weeks
column2: and I took it after while that he had found the going too hard and had chucked in the towel. And then
column3: one night not long before Christmas
column4: I came back to the flat pretty latish
column5: having been out dancing at the Embassy. I was fairly tired
column6: having swung a practically non-stop shoe from shortly after dinner till two AM
column7: and bed seemed to be indicated. Judge of my chagrin and all that sort of thing
column10: tottering to my room and switching on the light
column11: I observed the foul features of young Bingo all over the pillow. The blighter had appeared from nowhere and was in my bed
column12: sleeping like an infant with a sort of happy
column13: dreamy smile on his map."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 03:00|"three in the morning"|"‘Dash it all
column2: Bertie
column3: ’ said young Bingo querulously
column4: ‘don’t keep harping on your beastly bed. There’s another made up in the spare room. I saw Jeeves make it with my own eyes. I believe he meant it for me
column5: but I knew what a perfect host you were
column6: so I just turned in here. I say
column7: Bertie
column10: apparently fed up with the discussion about sleeping-quarters

column1: ‘Well
column2: it’s getting on for three in the morning.’

column1: ‘I was speaking figuratively
column2: you ass. I meant that hope has begun to dawn. About Mary Burgess
column3: you know. Sit down and I’ll tell you all about it.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap ~ 10:00|"about ten"|"‘Well
column2: there’s some good stuff in the first act
column3: and I can lift practically all the numbers. Then there’s that show at the Palace. I can see the matinee of that tomorrow before I leave. There’s sure to be some decent bits in that. Don’t you worry about my not being able to write a hit. Leave it to me
column4: laddie
column5: leave it to me. And now
column6: my dear old chap
column7: ’ said young Bingo
column9: ‘you mustn’t keep me up talking all night. It’s all right for you fellows who have nothing to do
column10: but I’m a busy man. Good night
column11: old thing. Close the door quietly after you and switch out the light. Breakfast
column14: what? Right-o. Good night.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 08:00|"eight in the morning"|"For the next three weeks I didn’t see Bingo. He became a sort of Voice Heard Off
column2: developing a habit of ringing me up on longdistance and consulting me on various points arising at rehearsal
column3: until the day when he got me out of bed at eight in the morning to ask whether I thought Merry Christmas! was a good tide. I told him then that this nuisance must now cease
column4: and after that he cheesed it
column5: and practically passed out of my life
column6: till one afternoon when I got back to the flat to dress for dinner and found Jeeves inspecting a whacking big poster sort of thing which he had draped over the back of an armchair."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap ~ 02:30|"about two-thirty"|"‘Bertie
column2: ’ said Eustace
column3: ‘you’ve got the programme nearly right
column4: but not quite. I envisage the evening’s events thus: We will toddle along to Giro’s after dinner. It’s an extension night
column5: isn’t it? Well
column6: that will see us through till about two-thirty or three.’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 02:30|vigils|"I suppose the fact of the matter is
column2: I’m not the man I was. I mean
column3: those all-night vigils don’t seem to fascinate me as they used to a few years ago. I can remember the time
column4: when I was up at Oxford
column5: when a Covent Garden ball till six in the morning
column6: with breakfast at the Hammams and probably a free fight with a few selected costermongers to follow
column7: seemed to me what the doctor ordered. But nowadays two o’clock is about my limit; and by two o’clock the twins were just settling down and beginning to go nicely."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: 06:00|"six in the morning"|"I suppose the fact of the matter is
column2: I’m not the man I was. I mean
column3: those all-night vigils don’t seem to fascinate me as they used to a few years ago. I can remember the time
column4: when I was up at Oxford

column6: with breakfast at the Hammams and probably a free fight with a few selected costermongers to follow
column7: seemed to me what the doctor ordered. But nowadays two o’clock is about my limit; and by two o’clock the twins were just settling down and beginning to go nicely."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column2: I’m not the man I was. I mean
column3: those all-night vigils don’t seem to fascinate me as they used to a few years ago. I can remember the time
column4: when I was up at Oxford

column6: with breakfast at the Hammams and probably a free fight with a few selected costermongers to follow
column7: seemed to me what the doctor ordered. But nowadays two o’clock is about my limit; and by two o’clock the twins were just settling down and beginning to go nicely."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ~ 09:00|"about nine in the morning"|"As far as I can remember
column2: we went on from Giro’s to play chemmy with some fellows I don’t recall having met before
column3: and it must have been about nine in the morning when we fetched up again at the flat. By which time
column4: I’m bound to admit
column5: as far as I was concerned the first careless freshness was beginning to wear off a bit. In fact
column6: I’d just got enough strength to say goodbye to the twins
column7: wish them a pleasant voyage and a happy and successful career in South Africa
column8: and stagger into bed. The last I remember was hearing the blighters chanting like larks under the cold shower
column9: breaking off from time to time to shout to Jeeves to rush along the eggs and bacon."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ~ 13:00|"about one in the afternoon"|"It must have been about one in the afternoon when I woke. I was feeling more or less like something the Pure Food Committee had rejected
column2: but there was one bright thought which cheered me up
column3: and that was that about now the twins would be leaning on the rail of the liner
column4: taking their last glimpse of the dear old homeland. Which made it all the more of a shock when the door opened and Claude walked in."|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"

column1: ap 07:45|"quarter to eight"|"‘Very good
column2: sir. The cigarettes are at your elbow
column3: sir. Dinner will be ready at a quarter to eight precisely
column4: unless you desire to dine out?’"|"The Inimitable Jeeves"|"P. G. Wodehouse"
